pages.raw_output:
<|ref|>title<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 186, 170, 200]]<|/det|>
# PHYSICS  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 207, 280, 222]]<|/det|>
Paper 1 Multiple Choice  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 250, 560, 291]]<|/det|>
Additional Materials: Multiple Choice Answer Sheet Soft clean eraser Soft pencil (type B or HB is recommended)  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 313, 386, 328]]<|/det|>
## READ THESE INSTRUCTIONS FIRST  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 343, 235, 357]]<|/det|>
Write in soft pencil.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 358, 600, 372]]<|/det|>
Do not use staples, paper clips, highlighters, glue or correction fluid.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 373, 890, 402]]<|/det|>
Write your name, Centre number and candidate number on the Answer Sheet in the spaces provided unless this has been done for you.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 416, 890, 445]]<|/det|>
There are forty questions on this paper. Answer all questions. For each question there are four possible answers A, B, C and D.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 445, 890, 460]]<|/det|>
Choose the one you consider correct and record your choice in soft pencil on the separate Answer Sheet.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 474, 555, 489]]<|/det|>
Read the instructions on the Answer Sheet very carefully.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 504, 764, 534]]<|/det|>
Each correct answer will score one mark. A mark will not be deducted for a wrong answer. Any working should be done in this booklet.

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 73, 124, 87]]<|/det|>
## Data  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[78, 98, 680, 545]]<|/det|>
speed of light in free space, \(c = 3.00\times 10^{8}\mathrm{ms}^{- 1}\) permeability of free space, \(\mu_{0} = 4\pi \times 10^{- 7}\mathrm{Hm}^{- 1}\) permittivity of free space, \(\epsilon_{0} = 8.85\times 10^{- 12}\mathrm{Fm}^{- 1}\) \((\frac{1}{4\pi\epsilon_{0}} = 8.99\times 10^{9}\mathrm{mF}^{- 1})\) elementary charge, \(e = 1.60\times 10^{- 19}\mathrm{C}\) the Planck constant, \(h = 6.63\times 10^{- 34}\mathrm{Js}\) unified atomic mass constant, \(u = 1.66\times 10^{- 27}\mathrm{kg}\) rest mass of electron, \(m_{\mathrm{e}} = 9.11\times 10^{- 31}\mathrm{kg}\) rest mass of proton, \(m_{\mathrm{p}} = 1.67\times 10^{- 27}\mathrm{kg}\) molar gas constant, \(R = 8.31\mathrm{JK}^{- 1}\mathrm{mol}^{- 1}\) the Avogadro constant, \(N_{\mathrm{A}} = 6.02\times 10^{23}\mathrm{mol}^{- 1}\) the Boltzmann constant, \(k = 1.38\times 10^{- 23}\mathrm{JK}^{- 1}\) gravitational constant, \(G = 6.67\times 10^{- 11}\mathrm{Nm}^{2}\mathrm{kg}^{- 2}\) acceleration of free fall, \(g = 9.81\mathrm{ms}^{- 2}\)

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 79, 168, 94]]<|/det|>
## Formulae  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 109, 325, 126]]<|/det|>
uniformly accelerated motion,  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 160, 275, 176]]<|/det|>
work done on/by a gas,  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 192, 262, 208]]<|/det|>
gravitational potential,  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 224, 254, 240]]<|/det|>
hydrostatic pressure,  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 255, 285, 271]]<|/det|>
pressure of an ideal gas,  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 293, 283, 309]]<|/det|>
simple harmonic motion,  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 325, 310, 342]]<|/det|>
velocity of particle in s.h.m.,  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 382, 221, 398]]<|/det|>
electric potential,  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 422, 245, 439]]<|/det|>
capacitors in series,  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 454, 256, 470]]<|/det|>
capacitors in parallel,  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 485, 316, 502]]<|/det|>
energy of charged capacitor,  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 516, 231, 533]]<|/det|>
resistors in series,  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 548, 242, 564]]<|/det|>
resistors in parallel,  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 580, 301, 597]]<|/det|>
alternating current/voltage,  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 612, 232, 629]]<|/det|>
radioactive decay,  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 643, 215, 660]]<|/det|>
decay constant,  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[450, 108, 570, 145]]<|/det|>
\[s = ut + \frac{1}{2} at^{2}\] \[\nu^{2} = u^{2} + 2as\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[450, 160, 530, 177]]<|/det|>
\[W = p\Delta V\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[455, 187, 542, 215]]<|/det|>
\[\phi = -\frac{Gm}{r}\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[455, 224, 527, 241]]<|/det|>
\[p = \rho gh\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[455, 250, 583, 281]]<|/det|>
\[p = \frac{1}{3}\frac{Nm}{V} < c^2 >\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[455, 292, 540, 310]]<|/det|>
\[a = -\omega^2 x\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[455, 325, 566, 343]]<|/det|>
\[\nu = \nu_0\cos \omega t\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[455, 349, 600, 377]]<|/det|>
\[\nu = \pm \omega \sqrt{x_0^2 - x^2}\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[455, 380, 546, 410]]<|/det|>
\[V = \frac{Q}{4\pi\epsilon_0r}\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[432, 421, 643, 440]]<|/det|>
\[1 / C = 1 / C_1 + 1 / C_2 + \ldots\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[452, 453, 600, 471]]<|/det|>
\[C = C_1 + C_2 + \ldots\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[432, 484, 536, 507]]<|/det|>
\[W = \frac{1}{2} QV\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[452, 518, 600, 536]]<|/det|>
\[R = R_1 + R_2 + \ldots\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[432, 549, 640, 568]]<|/det|>
\[1 / R = 1 / R_1 + 1 / R_2 + \ldots\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[452, 581, 560, 599]]<|/det|>
\[x = x_0\sin \omega t\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[452, 612, 582, 630]]<|/det|>
\[x = x_0\exp (-\lambda t)\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[452, 635, 540, 670]]<|/det|>
\[\lambda = \frac{0.693}{t_2}\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 73, 99, 90]]<|/det|>
<label>1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 73, 580, 90]]<|/det|>
Which quantity has the same base units as momentum?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 102, 292, 119]]<|/det|>
**A** density × energy

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 129, 377, 145]]<|/det|>
**B** density × volume × velocity

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 155, 285, 171]]<|/det|>
**C** pressure × area

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 182, 267, 198]]<|/det|>
**D** weight ÷ area

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[78, 228, 97, 246]]<|/det|>
<label>2</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 228, 416, 245]]<|/det|>
Vectors P and Q are drawn to scale.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[304, 253, 690, 313]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 329, 499, 346]]<|/det|>
Which diagram represents the vector \((\mathsf{P} + \mathsf{Q})\)?

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[267, 355, 730, 610]]<|/det|>

<pre>Space for working

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[78, 73, 94, 90]]<|/det|>
<label>3</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 73, 919, 106]]<|/det|>
What is the approximate kinetic energy of an Olympic athlete when running at maximum speed during a \(100 \text{m}\) race?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 115, 737, 133]]<|/det|>
A 400J B 4000J C 40 000J D 400 000J

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[78, 161, 96, 179]]<|/det|>
<label>4</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 161, 606, 178]]<|/det|>
Physical quantities can be classed as vectors or as scalars.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 191, 460, 208]]<|/det|>
Which pair of quantities are both vectors?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 219, 410, 235]]<|/det|>
A kinetic energy and elastic force

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 246, 325, 260]]<|/det|>
B momentum and time

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 272, 428, 287]]<|/det|>
C velocity and electric field strength

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 298, 351, 313]]<|/det|>
D weight and temperature

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[78, 343, 96, 361]]<|/det|>
<label>5</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 343, 920, 374]]<|/det|>
A student is given a reel of wire of diameter less than \(0.2 \text{mm}\) and is asked to find the density of the metal.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 387, 810, 404]]<|/det|>
Which pair of instruments would be most suitable for finding the volume of the wire?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 415, 370, 430]]<|/det|>
A balance and micrometer

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 441, 373, 456]]<|/det|>
B metre rule and micrometer

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 467, 405, 482]]<|/det|>
C metre rule and vernier calipers

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 494, 415, 508]]<|/det|>
D micrometer and vernier calipers

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 537, 245, 553]]<|/det|>
<pre>Space for working

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 73, 915, 90]]<|/det|>
The speed of a car is calculated from measurements of the distance travelled and the time taken.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 103, 648, 120]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 133, 621, 150]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 192, 700, 208]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 237, 95, 254]]<|/det|>
<label>8</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 237, 920, 269]]<|/det|>

<label>13</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 73, 919, 107]]<|/det|>
Two identical, perfectly elastic spheres have the same mass \(m\). They travel towards each other with the same speed \(v\) along a horizontal frictionless surface.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[270, 116, 725, 195]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 206, 779, 224]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 235, 141, 253]]<|/det|>
<label>A</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 235, 605, 253]]<|/det|>
The sum of their kinetic energies before impact is zero.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 263, 141, 281]]<|/det|>
<label>B</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 263, 620, 281]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 293, 139, 312]]<|/det|>
<label>C</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 293, 590, 311]]<|/det|>
The sum of their kinetic energies after impact is zero.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 320, 141, 338]]<|/det|>
<label>D</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 320, 590, 338]]<|/det|>
The sum of their kinetic energies after impact is \(mv^2\).

<label>14</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 628, 843, 645]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 656, 710, 675]]<|/det|>

change in momentum/Nsforce F/N
A48 000160
B480 0001600
C600 0002000
D600 00020 000

<label>18</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 73, 612, 90]]<|/det|>
A picture on a wall is supported by a wire looped over a nail.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[360, 101, 635, 205]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 219, 390, 236]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[115, 249, 470, 265]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 277, 693, 293]]<|/det|>
A 5.0N B 23N C 49N D 97N

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 322, 107, 339]]<|/det|>
<label>19</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 322, 919, 354]]<|/det|>
A piston in a gas supply pump has an area of \(500 \text{cm}^2\) and it moves a distance of \(30 \text{cm}\) during one stroke.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 367, 627, 384]]<|/det|>
The pump moves the gas against a fixed pressure of \(4000 \text{Pa}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 397, 586, 414]]<|/det|>
How much work is done by the piston during one stroke?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 426, 744, 443]]<|/det|>
A 60J B \(6.0\times 10^{3}\mathrm{J}\) C \(6.0\times 10^{5}\mathrm{J}\) D \(6.0\times 10^{7}\mathrm{J}\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 472, 107, 490]]<|/det|>
<label>20</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 472, 919, 504]]<|/det|>
A railway engine accelerates a train of total mass 1200 tonnes (1 tonne = 1000kg) from rest to a speed of \(75 \text{m s}^{-1}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 517, 693, 534]]<|/det|>
How much useful work must be done on the train to reach this speed?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 546, 744, 563]]<|/det|>
A \(1.7\times 10^{6}\mathrm{J}\) B \(3.4\times 10^{6}\mathrm{J}\) C \(1.7\times 10^{9}\mathrm{J}\) D \(3.4\times 10^{9}\mathrm{J}\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 592, 245, 607]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 73, 107, 90]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 73, 919, 106]]<|/det|> A crane is being used to lift containers off a ship. One container has a mass of \(14 000 \mathrm{~kg}\) and is being lifted vertically with a speed of \(3.2 \mathrm{~m} \mathrm{s}^{-1}\). <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 117, 919, 150]]<|/det|> The electric motor being used to supply the power to lift the container is using a current of 240 A at a potential difference of 2200 V. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 163, 420, 180]]<|/det|> What is the efficiency of the system? <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 191, 147, 209]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[160, 191, 201, 209]]<|/det|> 8.1% <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[280, 191, 368, 209]]<|/det|> B 8.5% <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[450, 191, 530, 209]]<|/det|> C 48% <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[616, 191, 697, 209]]<|/det|> D 83% <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 237, 107, 255]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 237, 920, 269]]<|/det|> Trains supply coal to a power station. The table below gives quantities describing the operation of the power station. <|ref|>table<|/ref|><|det|>[[259, 281, 740, 435]]<|/det|>

power station output\(P\)W
number of trains per day\(N\)
mass of coal on a train\(M\)kg
energy from 1 kg of coal\(J\)J
number of seconds in one day\(S\)
<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 448, 604, 465]]<|/det|> Which expression gives the efficiency of the power station? <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 475, 700, 505]]<|/det|> 
A \(\frac{PS}{NMJ}\) B \(\frac{PSN}{MJ}\) C \(\frac{NMJ}{PS}\) D \(\frac{NM}{PSJ}\)
